column2: Yes, to escape the disgrace I thought of drowning myself, Dounia, but as I looked into the water, I thought that if I had considered myself strong till now I'd better not be afraid of disgrace," he said, hurrying on.
column3: Yes, to escape the disgrace I thought of drowning myself, Dounia, but as I looked into the water, I thought that if I had considered myself strong till now I'd better not be afraid of disgrace," he said, hurrying on.

column2: It's pride, Dounia.
column3: It's pride, Dounia.

column2: Pride, Rodya.
column3: Pride, Rodya.

column2: There was a gleam of fire in his lustreless eyes; he seemed to be glad to think that he was still proud.
column3: There was a gleam of fire in his lustreless eyes; he seemed to be glad to think that he was still proud.

column2: You don't think, sister, that I was simply afraid of the water? he asked, looking into her face with a sinister smile.
column3: You don't think, sister, that I was simply afraid of the water? he asked, looking into her face with a sinister smile.

column2: Oh, Rodya, hush! cried Dounia bitterly.
column3: Oh, Rodya, hush! cried Dounia bitterly.

column2: Silence lasted for two minutes.
column3: Silence lasted for two minutes.

column2: He sat with his eyes fixed on the floor; Dounia stood at the other end of the table and looked at him with anguish.
column3: He sat with his eyes fixed on the floor; Dounia stood at the other end of the table and looked at him with anguish.

column2: Suddenly he got up.
column3: Suddenly he got up.

column2: It's late, it's time to go!	It's late, it's time to go!

column2: I am going at once to give myself up.
column3: I am going at once to give myself up.

column2: But I don't know why I am going to give myself up."
column3: But I don't know why I am going to give myself up."

column2: Big tears fell down her cheeks.
column3: Big tears fell down her cheeks.

column2: You are crying, sister, but can you hold out your hand to me?
column3: You are crying, sister, but can you hold out your hand to me?

column2: You doubted it?
column3: You doubted it?

column2: She threw her arms round him.
column3: She threw her arms round him.

column2: Aren't you half expiating your crime by facing the suffering? she cried, holding him close and kissing him.
column3: Aren't you half expiating your crime by facing the suffering? she cried, holding him close and kissing him.

column2: Crime?	Crime?

column2: What crime?" he cried in sudden fury.
column3: What crime?" he cried in sudden fury.

column2: That I killed a vile noxious insect, an old pawnbroker woman, of use to no one!...	That I killed a vile noxious insect, an old pawnbroker woman, of use to no one!...
column3: true

column2: Killing her was atonement for forty sins.
column3: Killing her was atonement for forty sins.

column2: She was sucking the life out of poor people.
column3: She was sucking the life out of poor people.

column2: Was that a crime?
column3: Was that a crime?

column2: I am not thinking of it and I am not thinking of expiating it, and why are you all rubbing it in on all sides?
column3: I am not thinking of it and I am not thinking of expiating it, and why are you all rubbing it in on all sides?

column2: 'A crime! a crime!' Only now I see clearly the imbecility of my cowardice, now that I have decided to face this superfluous disgrace.
column3: 'A crime! a crime!' Only now I see clearly the imbecility of my cowardice, now that I have decided to face this superfluous disgrace.

column2: It's simply because I am contemptible and have nothing in me that I have decided to, perhaps too for my advantage, as that...
column3: It's simply because I am contemptible and have nothing in me that I have decided to, perhaps too for my advantage, as that...

column2: Porfiry... suggested!"
column3: Porfiry... suggested!"

column2: Brother, brother, what are you saying?	Brother, brother, what are you saying?
column3: true

column2: Why, you have shed blood?" cried Dounia in despair.
column3: Why, you have shed blood?" cried Dounia in despair.

column2: Which all men shed, he put in almost frantically, "which flows and has always flowed in streams, which is spilt like champagne, and for which men are crowned in the Capitol and are called afterwards benefactors of mankind.
column3: Which all men shed, he put in almost frantically, "which flows and has always flowed in streams, which is spilt like champagne, and for which men are crowned in the Capitol and are called afterwards benefactors of mankind.

column2: Look into it more carefully and understand it!
column3: Look into it more carefully and understand it!

column2: I too wanted to do good to men and would have done hundreds, thousands of good deeds to make up for that one piece of stupidity, not stupidity even, simply clumsiness, for the idea was by no means so stupid as it seems now that it has failed.... (Everything seems stupid when it fails.) By that stupidity I only wanted to put myself into an independent position, to take the first step, to obtain means, and then everything would have been smoothed over by benefits immeasurable in comparison....
column3: I too wanted to do good to men and would have done hundreds, thousands of good deeds to make up for that one piece of stupidity, not stupidity even, simply clumsiness, for the idea was by no means so stupid as it seems now that it has failed.... (Everything seems stupid when it fails.) By that stupidity I only wanted to put myself into an independent position, to take the first step, to obtain means, and then everything would have been smoothed over by benefits immeasurable in comparison....

column2: But I... I couldn't carry out even the first step, because I am contemptible, that's what's the matter!
column3: But i.. I couldn't carry out even the first step, because I am contemptible, that's what's the matter!

column2: And yet I won't look at it as you do.
column3: And yet I won't look at it as you do.

column2: If I had succeeded I should have been crowned with glory, but now I'm trapped."
column3: If I had succeeded I should have been crowned with glory, but now I'm trapped."

column2: But that's not so, not so!	But that's not so, not so!
column3: true

column2: Brother, what are you saying?"
column3: Brother, what are you saying?"

column2: Ah, it's not picturesque, not aesthetically attractive!	Ah, it's not picturesque, not aesthetically attractive!
column3: true

column2: I fail to understand why bombarding people by regular siege is more honourable. The fear of appearances is the first symptom of impotence.
column3: I fail to understand why bombarding people by regular siege is more honourable. The fear of appearances is the first symptom of impotence.

column2: I've never, never recognised this more clearly than now, and I am further than ever from seeing that what I did was a crime.
column3: I've never, never recognised this more clearly than now, and I am further than ever from seeing that what I did was a crime.

column2: I've never, never been stronger and more convinced than now."
column3: I've never, never been stronger and more convinced than now."

column2: The colour had rushed into his pale exhausted face, but as he uttered his last explanation, he happened to meet Dounia's eyes and he saw such anguish in them that he could not help being checked.
column3: The colour had rushed into his pale exhausted face, but as he uttered his last explanation, he happened to meet Dounia's eyes and he saw such anguish in them that he could not help being checked.

column2: He felt that he had, anyway, made these two poor women miserable, that he was, anyway, the cause...
column3: He felt that he had, anyway, made these two poor women miserable, that he was, anyway, the cause...

column2: Dounia darling, if I am guilty forgive me (though I cannot be forgiven if I am guilty).	Dounia darling, if I am guilty forgive me (though I cannot be forgiven if I am guilty).

column2: Good-bye!
column3: Good bye!

column2: We won't dispute.
column3: We won't dispute.

column2: It's time, high time to go. Don't follow me, I beseech you, I have somewhere else to go....
column3: It's time, high time to go. Don't follow me, I beseech you, I have somewhere else to go....

column2: But you go at once and sit with mother.
column3: But you go at once and sit with mother.

column2: I entreat you to!
column3: I entreat you to!

column2: It's my last request of you.
column3: It's my last request of you.

column2: Don't leave her at all; I left her in a state of anxiety, that she is not fit to bear; she will die or go out of her mind.
column3: Don't leave her at all; I left her in a state of anxiety, that she is not fit to bear; she will die or go out of her mind.

column2: Be with her!
column3: Be with her!

column2: Razumihin will be with you.
column3: Razumihin will be with you.

column2: I've been talking to him....
column3: I've been talking to him....

column2: Don't cry about me: I'll try to be honest and manly all my life, even if I am a murderer.
column3: Don't cry about me: I'll try to be honest and manly all my life, even if I am a murderer.

column2: Perhaps I shall some day make a name.
column3: Perhaps I shall some day make a name.

column2: I won't disgrace you, you will see; I'll still show....
column3: I won't disgrace you, you will see; I'll still show....

column2: Now good-bye for the present," he concluded hurriedly, noticing again a strange expression in Dounia's eyes at his last words and promises.
column3: Now good bye for the present," he concluded hurriedly, noticing again a strange expression in Dounia's eyes at his last words and promises.

column2: Why are you crying?	Why are you crying?

column2: Don't cry, don't cry: we are not parting for ever!
column3: Don't cry, don't cry: we are not parting for ever!

column2: Ah, yes!
column3: Ah, yes!

column2: Wait a minute, I'd forgotten!"
column3: Wait a minute, I'd forgotten!"

column2: He went to the table, took up a thick dusty book, opened it and took from between the pages a little water-colour portrait on ivory.
column3: He went to the table, took up a thick dusty book, opened it and took from between the pages a little water colour portrait on ivory.

column2: It was the portrait of his landlady's daughter, who had died of fever, that strange girl who had wanted to be a nun.
column3: It was the portrait of his landlady's daughter, who had died of fever, that strange girl who had wanted to be a nun.

column2: For a minute he gazed at the delicate expressive face of his betrothed, kissed the portrait and gave it to Dounia.
column3: For a minute he gazed at the delicate expressive face of his betrothed, kissed the portrait and gave it to Dounia.

column2: I used to talk a great deal about it to her, only to her, he said thoughtfully.
column3: I used to talk a great deal about it to her, only to her, he said thoughtfully.

column2: To her heart I confided much of what has since been so hideously realised.	To her heart I confided much of what has since been so hideously realised.
column3: true

column2: Don't be uneasy," he returned to Dounia, "she was as much opposed to it as you, and I am glad that she is gone.
column3: Don't be uneasy," he returned to Dounia, "she was as much opposed to it as you, and I am glad that she is gone.

column2: The great point is that everything now is going to be different, is going to be broken in two," he cried, suddenly returning to his dejection. "Everything, everything, and am I prepared for it?
column3: The great point is that everything now is going to be different, is going to be broken in two," he cried, suddenly returning to his dejection. "Everything, everything, and am I prepared for it?

column2: Do I want it myself? They say it is necessary for me to suffer!
column3: Do I want it myself? They say it is necessary for me to suffer!

column2: What's the object of these senseless sufferings?
column3: What's the object of these senseless sufferings?

column2: shall I know any better what they are for, when I am crushed by hardships and idiocy, and weak as an old man after twenty years' penal servitude?
column3: shall I know any better what they are for, when I am crushed by hardships and idiocy, and weak as an old man after twenty years' penal servitude?

column2: And what shall I have to live for then?
column3: And what shall I have to live for then?

column2: Why am I consenting to that life now?
column3: Why am I consenting to that life now?

column2: Oh, I knew I was contemptible when I stood looking at the Neva at daybreak to-day!"
column3: Oh, I knew I was contemptible when I stood looking at the Neva at daybreak to day!"

column2: At last they both went out.
column3: At last they both went out.

column2: It was hard for Dounia, but she loved him. She walked away, but after going fifty paces she turned round to look at him again.
column3: It was hard for Dounia, but she loved him. She walked away, but after going fifty paces she turned round to look at him again.

column2: He was still in sight.
column3: He was still in sight.

column2: At the corner he too turned and for the last time their eyes met; but noticing that she was looking at him, he motioned her away with impatience and even vexation, and turned the corner abruptly.
column3: At the corner he too turned and for the last time their eyes met; but noticing that she was looking at him, he motioned her away with impatience and even vexation, and turned the corner abruptly.

column2: I am wicked, I see that, he thought to himself, feeling ashamed a moment later of his angry gesture to Dounia.
column3: I am wicked, I see that, he thought to himself, feeling ashamed a moment later of his angry gesture to Dounia.

column2: But why are they so fond of me if I don't deserve it?	But why are they so fond of me if I don't deserve it?

column2: Oh, if only I were alone and no one loved me and I too had never loved anyone!
column3: Oh, if only I were alone and no one loved me and I too had never loved anyone!

column2: _Nothing of all this would have happened._ But I wonder shall I in those fifteen or twenty years grow so meek that I shall humble myself before people and whimper at every word that I am a criminal?
column3: underscore Nothing of all this would have happened.underscore But I wonder shall I in those fifteen or twenty years grow so meek that I shall humble myself before people and whimper at every word that I am a criminal?

column2: Yes, that's it, that's it, that's what they are sending me there for, that's what they want.
column3: Yes, that's it, that's it, that's what they are sending me there for, that's what they want.

column2: Look at them running to and fro about the streets, every one of them a scoundrel and a criminal at heart and, worse still, an idiot.
column3: Look at them running to and fro about the streets, every one of them a scoundrel and a criminal at heart and, worse still, an idiot.

column2: But try to get me off and they'd be wild with righteous indignation.
column3: But try to get me off and they'd be wild with righteous indignation.

column2: Oh, how I hate them all!"
column3: Oh, how I hate them all!"

column2: He fell to musing by what process it could come to pass, that he could be humbled before all of them, indiscriminately--humbled by conviction. And yet why not?
column3: He fell to musing by what process it could come to pass, that he could be humbled before all of them, indiscriminately-humbled by conviction. And yet why not?

column2: It must be so.
column3: It must be so.

column2: Would not twenty years of continual bondage crush him utterly?
column3: Would not twenty years of continual bondage crush him utterly?

column2: Water wears out a stone.
column3: Water wears out a stone.

column2: And why, why should he live after that?
column3: And why, why should he live after that?

column2: Why should he go now when he knew that it would be so?
column3: Why should he go now when he knew that it would be so?

column2: It was the hundredth time perhaps that he had asked himself that question since the previous evening, but still he went.
